unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Improving Hypothesis Testing
question_text: The power of a hypothesis test can be increased by all of the following except

choices.text: Calculating the test statistic to more decimal places of accuracy.
Picking a particular alternative that is farther from the (null) hypothesized parameter.

solution:
Calculating the test statistic more accurately does not have any effect on the power of a statistical test.

The power of a hypothesis test is the probability of rejecting a false null hypothesis (a correct decision). Its formula is:

$$1-\beta$$

...where $\beta$ is the probability of not rejecting a null hypothesis when you should reject it.

This matches Choice 'C'.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; if one increases α, this decreases β, and thus increases the power.

Choices 'B' and 'D' are incorrect; increasing the sample size decreases the standard deviation of the sampling distribution, and thus makes the sample data more accurate, lessening the probability of making an incorrect decision. As a result, the power is then increased when the sample size is increased.

Choice 'E'is incorrect; moving the alternative further from the original null hypothesis makes it easier to reject a false null hypothesis, thus increasing the power of the test.
